text:

Commons license.

Your support will help
MIT OpenCourseWare

continue to offer high quality
educational resources for free.

To make a donation or
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare
at ocw.mit.edu.

IDA GALL: This is what we
use, called ACE Competitive
Excellence.

And it's not only
at Pratt & Whitney.

United Technologies is
Otis, Carrier, Sikorsky,
[INAUDIBLE]--

I mean, they have a lot
of different divisions.

But we all are working to the
ACE Competitive Excellence
operating system.

3 defines daily
management system.
It defines the humanware.

It defines the culture, the
hardware, and the competency.

Which one up here is
the hardest one to do?
Culture.

All of you guys here
are super smart.

You guys could
probably write programs

and do all kinds of neat things
and really get things going.

But the hardest part
of this is the people.

If you don't have
the people engaged,

and if they don't see
what's in it for them,
it's not going to happen.
What else does it take?

Can I just walk into Pratt
& Whitney, go to my desk,

sit down, and say, boy,
I want us to be ACE Gold.

I want to be the best
company in the world.
What does it take?

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
commitment.
IDA GALL: Commitment from whom?

AUDIENCE: From
[INAUDIBLE] sponsorship
from your higher ups.
IDA GALL: Correct.

You have to have sponsorship
from the higher ups.

It has to be part
of the culture.
It's a set of tools.

It's a way to do
continuous improvement.

And competency is really
just the training part of it,

making sure that people
understand the common language
across.

The really neat thing
about Achieving Competitive

Excellence-- how many of you
have ever heard about ACE,

Achieving Competitive
Excellence?
And you can't raise your hand--

I know you can't raise
your hand in back.

It is like Six Sigma Lean
to United Technologies.
It has the same--

we have what we call
process certification that

talks about the upper
and lower control limits
for statistical control.
It's our Six Sigma program.

So if you're ever out and about
with maybe Carrier or Sikorsky,

and somebody says ACE, that's
what they're talking about.

How many of you ever
heard of George David?
Nobody back there.
Nobody here.
He is our CEO.
And he's retiring this year.

And Louis Chenevert is
going to be taking over.

But George David truly believes
in ACE, Achieving Competitive
Excellence.
He'll go to Wall Street.
He talks about it.
He believes it.

And if you just read this
comment here, it was in 2003,

but if you look in
articles in Business Week,

he was named CEO of
the decade in 2006.

And he is a strong
driver behind us.
And what makes it important?

Good quality,
delighted customers,

also looking at
employee fulfillment,

also looking at EH&S,
environmental health

and safety, and it's
also looking at--

even though the stock
market's been doing lousy--
the stockholders.
It all plays together.
And it's a common language.
For many years at Pratt--

I've been at Pratt
for a long time--

and you'd have the
flavor of the month--

TQM, work simplification,
queue plus--

but if you went outside
of Pratt & Whitney

and went to another division
of United Technologies,

they didn't know what
you were talking about.
Nobody spoke the same language.

So ACE is a common language
across all divisions.
Culture.

I can tell you when I walk
into a plant, you can see it.

You actually truly can
see an ACE organization,
a gold organization.

And I'll talk about the
different levels coming up
here.

And top line, leadership
is engaged at all levels.

And I don't see-- our friend
from the Army back there,

you were talking about
the frozen middle.

Yeah, we have the
frozen middle too.

We have lots of excitement down
here, lots of excitement here,

but we're having a little
problem with the middle part.
But we're getting there.

Pratt has been doing
this since 1996.

And at Pratt & Whitney right
now, we have 22% gold sites.

This is 2008, ladies
and gentlemen.

So that should tell you how
long this process takes.
It's a slow process.

But once you get it
going, it's amazing.
It should look familiar.

It's a learning
process when you first
start continuous improvement.

A lot of people think, I'm
going to move the waste paper

can from that corner of the
room to the other corner

of the room, and
I'm saving steps.

You've got to think
bigger, guys and gals.
You've got to think bigger.
What is your customer?

What are your objectives
for the company?
What's your business strategy?

Somebody was talking
earlier today

about you need to look
at the projects that
have the most value.

What's going to make some
impact to the company?

How are you going to
really show some results?

And so you need to
look at the customer,

the business strategy,
where are some

of the opportunities,
discrepancy,

here's quality,
and your processes.

And now you've
heard earlier today

about they talk about process
flow and looking for problems.

You do a value stream
map, you see the problems.

I'm not quite sure why
they separate those two.
But it's interesting.
Any of you familiar with Deming?

I should see a few more
hands than just a couple.
Plan, do, check, act, folks.

It's the continuous
cycle of improvement.

Why do they call it
continuous improvement?
It never ends.

You just keep improving,
keep improving.

You establish your vision,
your goals, your strategy--

metrics is perhaps one of the
most challenging parts of doing
continuous improvement.

I cannot tell you how
many projects I walked

in on and said, hey, guys,
what are you going to measure?
Is it throughput?
Is it improving your schedule?
What are you trying to do?
What's your metric?

How are you going to
measure the improvement?
Very key at identifying gaps.

And I've heard you guys talk
about root cause analysis.
Have they gone through--
AUDIENCE: Yup.

IDA GALL: Root cause, five
whys, fishbone diagram?
OK.

Now does any of
this look familiar?
But you see the title?
It's the same.

5S, 6S, value stream
management, process control
and certification--

once again, that's
our Six Sigma.

That's how we do
process cert to make

sure that we have
things under control
and measuring the variation.

3P, total product
maintenance-- yes?

AUDIENCE: We didn't
talk about [INAUDIBLE]..

IDA GALL: These are more for
manufacturing opportunities.

Production preparation
process, sounds crazy,

but they do this at Hamilton
Sundstrand and Pratt & Whitney
Canada.

And I wish I would have brought
you the videos because it's
really cool.

What they'll do, is they'll
just lay it out with cardboard

and actually run
through the process

to see where they
can improve things.

And it's a way of
designing ahead of time

instead of setting up the
manufacturing area and floor

without actually thinking about
what the flow is going to be.
It's very useful.

Market feedback analysis--
oh excuse me, TPM.

When you have a machine,
you need to keep it working.
How do you do that?

You keep ensuring
that it's working.
And you keep taking care of it.

How many of you change
your oil in your car?

This gentleman here,
Harvey, you're scaring me.

You're like, maybe--
when was the last time
you changed your oil?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
IDA GALL: Oh, OK.

And set up reduction,
that's just

a way of when they're
setting up machines,

if they're making
this part, what

do you have to do to set
up the part in the machine?

And how can you improve
on that process?

And there's a lot of work
that can be done in that area.
And that's another thing too.

Pratt & Whitney, we've
been in the lean book--

we've been written
up into some books.
Jim Womack has written about us.

First off, we started in
a manufacturing floor.

Boy, there's lots of things to
do in the manufacturing floor.

And they really went out
there and fixed things.

But then they realized
it's above the floor that's
your opportunities.

Now we're dealing with our
friends in engineering.
And that's another story.

But we're getting
there and trying

to get them to understand
how important it

is to improve and to
design ahead of time

instead of waiting
until something happens
and then fixing it.

Market feedback
analysis, that's just

a way of getting
customer feedback.

I think you guys are probably
going to be filling out

a customer feed-- at
the end of the class--
I hope.

QCPC, this is a
way that we collect
what we call opportunities.

When you're doing
a process, is there

anything that
impedes the process?

If I'm making is
this book over here,

and I can't get the printer
to fix that label, that would
be considered a turn back.
And you collect that data.

And like you were saying before,
it is absolutely data driven.

Steve Finger, the president
of Pratt & Whitney,

is absolutely passionate
about this discussion.

When he's in a meeting
with you, and you

start waving your hands
about things being wrong,
he will say, show me the data.

If you don't have
the data, I don't
want to hear the discussion.
So data is key.
Mistake proofing.

How many of you
use computers here?
How many of Bill Gates--

Microsoft Software
and some of the things

that he's put in there
is mistake proofing,

to make sure you
don't make mistakes.

Errors, this is something very
unique to Pratt & Whitney.

I'm not sure if this
is across the industry.

What happens is when
you're designing an engine,

it takes years to
design an engine.

There's processes and
gates that you go through.

The passport process checks
throughout the life cycle

of that engine to
ensure that you

don't go to market
at the wrong time,

that you are
developing something
that's not technically sound--

it's a way to actually check the
process of developing an engine

to ensure that it's
not any turn backs.
AUDIENCE: Decision gates.
IDA GALL: Decision gates.

And we are big on
passport process.

In fact, we're in
the process of doing
some continuous improvement.

ACE Competencies, Ito
University, ACE training,
high-impact ACE teams--
great.

High-impact ACE teams are
looking at the big issues

throughout the
company and working
across the value streams.

And I know you guys talked
about values dreams.

And I don't know what level
you talked about values dreams.

Are you talking value
streams, or are you

talking enterprise
value streams?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] lower.
IDA GALL: Lower.
OK.
Some day think higher because--
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

IDA GALL: It really
makes-- and sharing

of best practices,
Pratt & Whitney and I

think a lot of organizations
suffer from this.

We don't really
take the opportunity
to share best practices.

We really don't stop
and say, good job.

Now they have developed a
web page where they actually
put best practices out there.

Qualifying bronze,
silver, and gold,

these are different
levels of competency.
And there's a Shingijutsu--

I don't even know if I'm
pronouncing that right--

but they have something
similar to this.

And this actually came
from the Olympics.

And believe me, to
get to ACE Gold,

you have to be 100% on
time delivery, 0 escapes--

the metrics are
what we call a BHAG.

They are some very serious
metrics to get to ACE Gold.

And this is just the progression
that organizations go through.

Steve Finger had put out an
edict about two years ago,

by May of 2008, all of Pratt
& Whitney would be solid gold.
Steve has good intentions.
Steve is a great leader.

But we're not at ACE Gold
for all of Pratt & Whitney.

And I think about a month
ago, he came to the--

actually, I was in a meeting
with him in October--

he came to the realization,
may not get there,

but it's making
the great strides
to get towards that goal.
And he's still pushing it.

In fact, this morning
I just received

an email about how excited he is
about ACE and where it's going

and how it's going
to help us for 2008.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]?
IDA GALL: Sure.

AUDIENCE: One quick question, is
any part of United Technologies
not ACE qualifying yet?

IDA GALL: There are
different segments of it.
We are about 51%.

There's parts of them
that are at 10%--
very low.
They haven't really gone as far.

In fact, out of
all the divisions,
Pratt & Whitney is the leader.

But the other ones are
still getting there.
Yes?

AUDIENCE: With regard
to the different levels,

are they based on
more a maturity
model for adoption of ACE?

Or is it more about
meeting objectives
from the business perspective?
IDA GALL: Both.

When they come out and
do an ACE assessment

from core quality,
the ACE office,

they will look for what we
have control towers, which

you guys would probably call
data cards or quality cards

or whatever, that actually
have certain metrics that
have to be met.

Those have to be solid
gold for 12 months.

I mean, it's some really tough
metrics that they're driven by.

And then when they go
and do the assessment,

they randomly walk
through the area.

They do the success, which is
our 5S, which we have safety

as the success, and they go
through and actually see,
are people engaged?
Are they actually talking it?
Are they actually doing it?
So it's a two-fold.

And let me tell you,
the metric one, OK.
The hard one, the people--
very tough.

And here's George David being
quoted in the Financial Times.

He talks about Six Sigma
is done by black belts.

He's talking about
ACE there also.
And then here, I just wanted--
what is his secret?
And how does he maintain this?

Clear, consistent,
mature, repetitive
throughout operating systems.
And here's Louis.

This is the gentleman
that's going to take
George's place this year.
And you can see, December 13th--

this was 2007-- talking
about the shares, earnings--

by the way, today we're
at $74 per share UTC--
earnings per share.

And then if you look a little
bit further down his quote,

here again he's talking about
the ACE operating system.
George is moving on.
Louis' coming in.
It isn't going to stop.
So that's the good news.

Now a lot of people say,
does this stuff really work?
What are you doing?

I think the stock
market can show you
that it is working for us.

And also here's some
friends from Global Services
Engineering.

Believe me, if you can get
the engineering folks engaged,
this is good stuff.

This is talking to some
quotes from this group.

I just want to show
you some numbers here.

CACTUS wires is a way that
we communicate back and forth
with our customers.

70% to 98%-- overdue wires
reduced from 13 to 9,

72% improvement in turn
time, 40% improvement

and turn time for
processing with engineering.

Survey-- and I'm
not quite sure how

I do this-- but for
employee fulfillment,

65% employee fulfillment
is the standard.

That's what we're
being told by HR.

So anything above 65%
is considered gold.

And then improvement
on the website, here's
another one from engineering.
Customer feedback is 6.2.
Employee survey is 71%.
0 lost time injuries.

Quality assurance, data
delivered 100% on time.

Engineering standard
work, how many times

do you go in and
improve process,

everybody has the
cake and the banners,

and the pictures are taken,
and everybody walks away,
but nobody's written it down?

Nobody is going to be able
to repeat this process again.

So standard work
is very important.

Procedures-- a way
to let people know
how to continue doing the job.

Here we go, moving
from ACE silver to gold
is directly attributed to.

And I don't want to
read this whole thing.

But I just want to throw
some quotes in here

from different people
throughout the organization.
And then this is AEDC.

If you remember AEDC,
we did some work--

LAI did some work with
them a couple of years ago.

But they have
really moved ahead.

94 straight months
without lost time injury--
just goes on and on and on.

Standard work-- just some
of the data showing you here
what's going on.

And then that is actually a
site manager Pratt & Whitney

talking about how ACE has really
helped them on their journey
to improvement.
And the Journey continues.
Like I said, we are only at 22%.

You imagine when Pratt
& Whitney is at 100%?
It'll be amazing.
Is there any questions?
AUDIENCE: I got a question.
IDA GALL: Sure.

AUDIENCE: And you
alluded to it, but let
me just put it on the table.

Why go into organizations
and ask, what's

the most difficult group of
people in your organization

to buy into the
lean transformation,
the answer's always the same.
The frozen middle.

People in the middle,
because they're

worried whether their job
really adds value or not.

And the engineers-- as engineers
say, it doesn't apply to me.

IDA GALL: It
doesn't apply to me.
AUDIENCE: Yeah.
IDA GALL: [INAUDIBLE]

AUDIENCE: So what are you
doing at Pratt & Whitney
to get the engineers on board?

IDA GALL: Paul Adams, who's
the executive there, he's

on this working together team,
and they all talk across--
do the cross talk.

I now sit in the
engineering building.

And I cannot tell you how many
times I hear them talking about

the control towers, their
metrics, their turn backs--
they're talkative.

They were perhaps the last
group to flip that switch--
a lot of pushback.

And that's one thing-- and if
you remember this George David,
why is he such a great leader?

You've got to repeat the
same message over and over
again for people to get it.
And they're getting it.
They have to get it.

AUDIENCE: We want
to thank you for--

Ida drove two hours to get
here this morning [INAUDIBLE]..

IDA GALL: And let me tell
you, Massachusetts drivers
[WHISTLES]--
[LAUGHTER]
--scary.

AUDIENCE: Sharing a little
certificate of appreciation.
IDA GALL: Oh, thank you so much.
AUDIENCE: Thank you.
IDA GALL: Thanks.
[APPLAUSE]
